Child_Food_Insecurity_Rate.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
Child_Food_Insecurity_Rate.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
Child_Food_Insecurity_Rate.statement: {value} of the population of children in {features.name} are food insecure.

Cost_Per_Meal.long_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food, as estimated by the Current Population Survey, divided by 21 (assuming three meals a day, seven days a week). This amount has been adjusted to reflect local food prices and relevant taxes.
Cost_Per_Meal.short_description: The average weekly dollar amount food-secure individuals report spending on food.
Cost_Per_Meal.statement: The average meal cost in {features.name} is {value}.

NAICS21_Herfindalh_Hirschman_index.long_description: employment concentration by few businesses : \[Herfindalh\_Hirschman\_index=\sqrt{\sum{business\_employment\_share^{2}}}\] in NAICS21 industry. The Mining, Quarrying, and Oil and Gas Extraction sector comprises establishments that extract naturally occurring mineral solids, such as coal and ores; liquid minerals, such as crude petroleum; and gases, such as natural gas. The term mining is used in the broad sense to include quarrying, well operations, beneficiating (e.g., crushing, screening, washing, and flotation), and other preparation customarily performed at the mine site, or as a part of mining activity.\href{https://www.census.gov/naics/?input=21&chart=2022}{NAICS code: 21}.. Available for US businesses.

The Mining, Quarrying, and Oil and Gas Extraction sector comprises establishments that extract naturally occurring mineral solids, such as coal and ores; liquid minerals, such as crude petroleum; and gases, such as natural gas. The term mining is used in the broad sense to include quarrying, well operations, beneficiating (e.g., crushing, screening, washing, and flotation), and other preparation customarily performed at the mine site, or as a part of mining activity.\href{https://www.census.gov/naics/?input=21&chart=2022}{NAICS code: 21}.

NAICS22_Herfindalh_Hirschman_index.long_description: employment concentration by few businesses : \[Herfindalh\_Hirschman\_index=\sqrt{\sum{business\_employment\_share^{2}}}\] in NAICS22 industry. The Utilities sector comprises establishments engaged in the provision of the following utility services: electric power, natural gas, steam supply, water supply, and sewage removal. Within this sector, the specific activities associated with the utility services provided vary by utility: electric power includes generation, transmission, and distribution; natural gas includes distribution; steam supply includes provision and/or distribution; water supply includes treatment and distribution; and sewage removal includes collection, treatment, and disposal of waste through sewer systems and sewage treatment facilities.\href{https://www.census.gov/naics/?input=22&chart=2022}{NAICS code: 22}.. Available for US businesses.

NAICS48_49_Herfindalh_Hirschman_index.long_description: employment concentration by few businesses : \[Herfindalh\_Hirschman\_index=\sqrt{\sum{business\_employment\_share^{2}}}\] in NAICS48_49 industry. The Transportation and Warehousing sector includes industries providing transportation of passengers and cargo, warehousing and storage for goods, scenic and sightseeing transportation, and support activities related to modes of transportation. Establishments in these industries use transportation equipment or transportation related facilities as a productive asset. The type of equipment depends on the mode of transportation. The modes of transportation are air, rail, water, road, and pipeline.\href{https://www.census.gov/naics/?input=48&chart=2022}{NAICS code: 48-49}.. Available for US businesses.

The Transportation and Warehousing sector includes industries providing transportation of passengers and cargo, warehousing and storage for goods, scenic and sightseeing transportation, and support activities related to modes of transportation. Establishments in these industries use transportation equipment or transportation related facilities as a productive asset. The type of equipment depends on the mode of transportation. The modes of transportation are air, rail, water, road, and pipeline.\href{https://www.census.gov/naics/?input=48&chart=2022}{NAICS code: 48-49}.

The Real Estate and Rental and Leasing sector comprises establishments primarily engaged in renting, leasing, or otherwise allowing the use of tangible or intangible assets, and establishments providing related services. The Management of Companies and Enterprises sector comprises (1) establishments that hold the securities of (or other equity interests in) companies and enterprises for the purpose of owning a controlling interest or influencing management decisions or (2) establishments (except government establishments) that administer, oversee, and manage establishments of the company or enterprise and that normally undertake the strategic or organizational planning and decision-making role of the company or enterprise. Establishments that administer, oversee, and manage may hold the securities of the company or enterprise.\href{https://www.census.gov/naics/?input=55&chart=2022}{NAICS code: 55}.. The Management of Companies and Enterprises sector comprises (1) establishments that hold the securities of (or other equity interests in) companies and enterprises for the purpose of owning a controlling interest or influencing management decisions or (2) establishments (except government establishments) that administer, oversee, and manage establishments of the company or enterprise and that normally undertake the strategic or organizational planning and decision-making role of the company or enterprise. Establishments that administer, oversee, and manage may hold the securities of the company or enterprise.\href{https://www.census.gov/naics/?input=55&chart=2022}{NAICS code: 55}.. Available for US businesses.

NAICS61_Herfindalh_Hirschman_index.long_description: employment concentration by few businesses : \[Herfindalh\_Hirschman\_index=\sqrt{\sum{business\_employment\_share^{2}}}\] in NAICS61 industry. The Educational Services sector comprises establishments that provide instruction and training in a wide variety of subjects. This instruction and training is provided by specialized establishments, such as schools, colleges, universities, and training centers. These establishments may be privately owned and operated for profit or not for profit, or they may be publicly owned and operated. They may also offer food and/or accommodation services to their students.\href{https://www.census.gov/naics/?input=61&chart=2022}{NAICS code: 61}.. Available for US businesses.

This instruction and training is provided by specialized establishments, such as schools, colleges, universities, and training centers. These establishments may be privately owned and operated for profit or not for profit, or they may be publicly owned and operated. They may also offer food and/or accommodation services to their students.\href{https://www.census.gov/naics/?input=61&chart=2022}{NAICS code: 61}.. Available for US businesses.

Num_Child_Food_Insecure.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity. Food-insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
Num_Child_Food_Insecure.short_description: Food insecure children are those children living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
Num_Child_Food_Insecure.statement: The population of food insecure children in {features.name} is {value}.

adequate.long_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU) index, also known as the Kotelchuck index, with a rating of adequate. Adequate prenatal care occurs when prenatal care begins from 1st through 4th month and the proportion of the number of recommended visits is between 80% and 109%. The recommended number of prenatal care visits received from the time prenatal care began until the time of delivery is defined by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.

affordability_index.long_description:
The Affordability index is developed to measure the proportion of income spent on housing and transportation. The affordability index is obtained from the Housing + Transportation (H+T) Affordability Index data provided by Center for Neighborhood Technology (CNT). The index of affordability is calculated by combining housing and transportation costs in a neighborhood and dividing that number by income . H+T index provides three different affordability index to account for different households like Regional Typical Household, Regional Moderate Household and National Typical Household. In our analysis, we focused on the Regional Typical Household. 
 We downloaded and cleaned the dataset from the CNT H+T index website for years 2015, 2019, and 2020.  To fill in the missing data for the years 2016-2018, we performed interpolation using the available data points from 2015 and 2019. Additionally, for the year 2021, we estimated employment access values by multiplying the rate of change observed from 2019 to 2020 by the values for the year 2020. Employment access data is available at the tract, county and health district level for the state of Virginia.
affordability_index.short_description: Affordability index is developed to measure the proportion of income spent on housing and transportation

sources.name: Housing + Transportation Affordability Index, Center for Neighborhood Technology

age_20_64_count_direct.long_description: The population estimates between age 20 and 64. 5-year ACS estimates in provided census geolevels. For non-census geolevels (such as zip codes), spatial overlaps are calculated between census block groups and target regions, then the value of each block group is aggregated to any intersecting target region based on proportion of overlap. Redistribution to non-census geolevels was performed using the redistribute R package.
age_20_64_count_direct.long_name: The population estimates between age 20 and 64.
age_20_64_count_direct.short_description: The population estimates between age 20 and 64.

sources.name: American Community Survey

sources.location: Health & Human Service > Human Services Regions
sources.name: Fairfax County Geospatial Data

age_20_64_count_direct.statement: The population between age 20 and 64 is {value} in {region_name}.

age_20_64_count_parcels.long_description: The population estimates between age 20 and 64. 5-year ACS estimates in provided census geolevels. For non-census geolevels (such as zip codes), spatial overlaps are calculated between census block groups and parcels, then the value of each block group is divided across all living units within each intersecting parcel. Once parcel-level values are assigned, spatial overlaps are calculated between parcels and target regions such that parcel values can be aggregated to each intersecting target region based on proportion of overlap. Redistribution to non-census geolevels was performed using the redistribute R package.

age_65_plus_percent_direct.long_description: The percent of the population over age 64. 5-year ACS estimates in provided census geolevels. For non-census geolevels (such as zip codes), spatial overlaps are calculated between census block groups and target regions, then the value of each block group is aggregated to any intersecting target region based on proportion of overlap. Redistribution to non-census geolevels was performed using the redistribute R package.

age_65_plus_percent_parcels.long_description: The percent of the population over age 64. 5-year ACS estimates in provided census geolevels. For non-census geolevels (such as zip codes), spatial overlaps are calculated between census block groups and parcels, then the value of each block group is divided across all living units within each intersecting parcel. Once parcel-level values are assigned, spatial overlaps are calculated between parcels and target regions such that parcel values can be aggregated to each intersecting target region based on proportion of overlap. Redistribution to non-census geolevels was performed using the redistribute R package.

average_years_schooling.long_description: The Education Index measures the average education level achieved by the adult population in an area. This is based on the average years of schooling in an area. The calculation used to calculate the index can be found in (Bennett, D.L. Educational Inequailty in the United States: Methodology and Historical Estimates of Education Gini Coefficients. Econ. Modeling Microeconom. Stud. Health 2001). Higher educational attainment has been shown to have positive impacts on economic earning and positive health outcomes.

daycare_ratio.long_description: Number of day care seats per 1,000 children under 15 years of age, which accept at least ages 4 to 10, as calculated within floating catchment areas. Catchment area ratios are based on the population of children under 15 within block groups (as estimated in the American Community Survey), capacity of eligible day care providers (as reported by the Virginia Department of Social Services), and travel times between block group centroids and day care locations (as calculated with the Open Source Routing Machine). Catchment areas are weighted by travel time with a Gaussian function with scale of 18, which are normalized for each consumer (for a 3-step floating catchment area), as calculated by the catchment R package.

earnings_per_job.long_description:
Earnings per job is calculated based on the GDP and Personal Income table from the Bureau of Economic Analysis(BEA).  Earnings per job is total earnings divided by total number of jobs. Total earnings is the sum of wages and salaries, supplements to wages and salaries, and proprietor’s income. Wages and salaries refer to the monetary remuneration of employees; it includes compensation of corporate officers; commissions, tips, and bonuses, compensation plans, such as 401(k) plans; and receipts in kind, or pay-in-kind, that represent income to the recipient. Supplements to wages and salaries consists of employer contributions for employee pension and insurance funds and employer contributions for government social insurance. Proprietor’s income is the current-production income (including the income in kind) of sole proprietorships and partnerships and of tax-exempt cooperatives.

Raw data observations are generally per county/city; however, some observations involve multiple counties/cities. For example, Fairfax County, Fairfax City and Falls Church City are grouped into one observation in the raw data.  We split the multi-county/city raw data observations into multiple observations so that one observation corresponds to only one county/city.  We set the value of each split individual observation to be that of the corresponding raw multi-county/city observation.

These are the multi-county/city groupings in the raw data: Albemarle County, Charlottesville; Alleghany County, Covington; Augusta County, Staunton, Waynesboro; Campbell County,  Lynchburg; Carroll County, Galax; Dinwiddie County, Colonial Heights, Petersburg; Fairfax County, Fairfax City, Falls Church; Frederick County, Winchester; Greensville County, Emporia; Henry County,  Martinsville; James City County, Williamsburg; Montgomery County, Radford; Pittsylvania County, Danville; Prince George County, Hopewell; Prince William County, Manassas, Manassas Park; Roanoke County, Salem; Rockbridge County, Buena Vista, Lexington; Rockingham County, Harrisonburg; Southampton County, Franklin; Spotsylvania County, Fredericksburg; Washington County, Bristol; Wise County, Norton; York County, Poquoson.

employment_access_index.long_description:
Employment access measures the accessibility of jobs in a particular area. Poor job access can include barriers such as distance from residents and transportation availability. The employment access index is obtained from the Housing + Transportation (H+T) Affordability Index data provided by Center for Neighborhood Technology (CNT).  H+T calculated the index using a gravity model. The index is calculated by summing the total number of jobs divided by the square of the distance to those jobs. The index is based on jobs and distance decay function. 
 We downloaded and cleaned the dataset from the CNT H+T index website for years 2015, 2019, and 2020. To fill in the missing data for the years 2016-2018, we performed interpolation using the available data points from 2015 and 2019. Additionally, for the year 2021, we estimated employment access values by multiplying the rate of change observed from 2019 to 2020 by the values for the year 2020. Employment access data is available at the tract, county and health district level for the state of Virginia.
employment_access_index.short_description: Employment access is the job accessibility at a location

sources.name: Housing + Transportation Affordability Index, Center for Neighborhood Technology

food_access_percentage.long_description: Share of tract population that are low income individuals beyond 1 mile from supermarket. The criteria for identifying a census tract as low income are from the Department of Treasury’s New Markets Tax Credit (NMTC) program. This program defines a low-income census tract as any tract where:The tract’s poverty rate is 20 percent or greater; or The tract’s median family income is less than or equal to 80 percent of the State-wide median family income; or The tract is in a metropolitan area and has a median family income less than or equal to 80 percent of the metropolitan area's median family income. low access to healthy food: being far from a supermarket, supercenter, or large grocery store. A census tract is considered to have low access if a significant number or share of individuals in the tract is far from a supermarket. Three measures of food access based on distance to a supermarket. If 1 mile from the supermarket information is not available, use half a mile information. NULL corresonds to zero values.
food_access_percentage.short_description: Low access, low-income population at 1 mile from supermarket.

food_insecure_cnt.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. This measure is an estimate of the number of people in food insecure households. Food insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
food_insecure_cnt.long_name: Estimated number of food insecure people
food_insecure_cnt.short_description: Food insecure people live in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).

gender_female_count_direct.long_description: The count of females in the total population. 5-year ACS estimates in provided census geolevels. For non-census geolevels (such as zip codes), spatial overlaps are calculated between census block groups and target regions, then the value of each block group is aggregated/disaggregated to any intersecting target region based on proportion of overlap. Redistribution to non-census geolevels was performed using the redistribute R package.
gender_female_count_direct.long_name: The count of females in population.
gender_female_count_direct.short_description: The count of females in population.

sources.location: 5-Year estimates, table S0101, via the API
sources.name: American Community Survey

sources.location: Health & Human Service > Human Services Regions
sources.name: Fairfax County Geospatial Data

gender_female_count_parcels.long_description: The count of females in the total population. 5-year ACS estimates in provided census geolevels. For non-census geolevels (such as zip codes), spatial overlaps are calculated between census block groups and parcels, then the value of each block group is divided across all living units within each intersecting parcel. Once parcel-level values are assigned, spatial overlaps are calculated between parcels and target regions such that parcel values can be aggregated to each intersecting target region based on proportion of overlap. Redistribution to non-census geolevels was performed using the redistribute R package.
gender_female_count_parcels.long_name: The count of females in population.
gender_female_count_parcels.short_description: The count of females in population.

gender_female_percent_direct.long_description: The percent of females in the total population. 5-year ACS estimates in provided census geolevels. For non-census geolevels (such as zip codes), spatial overlaps are calculated between census block groups and target regions, then the value of each block group is aggregated/disaggregated to any intersecting target region based on proportion of overlap. Redistribution to non-census geolevels was performed using the redistribute R package.

gender_female_percent_parcels.long_description: The percent of females in the total population. 5-year ACS estimates in provided census geolevels. For non-census geolevels (such as zip codes), spatial overlaps are calculated between census block groups and parcels, then the value of each block group is divided across all living units within each intersecting parcel. Once parcel-level values are assigned, spatial overlaps are calculated between parcels and target regions such that parcel values can be aggregated to each intersecting target region based on proportion of overlap. Redistribution to non-census geolevels was performed using the redistribute R package.
gender_female_percent_parcels.long_name: The percent of females in the total population.

gini_index.long_description: The Gini Index is a summary measure of income inequality. The Gini coefficient incorporates the detailed shares data into a single statistic, which summarizes the dispersion of income across the entire income distribution. The Gini coefficient ranges from 0, indicating perfect equality (where everyone receives an equal share), to 1, perfect inequality (where only one recipient or group of recipients receives all the income). The Gini is based on the difference between the Lorenz curve (the observed cumulative income distribution) and the notion of a perfectly equal income distribution.
gini_index.short_description: The Gini Index is a summary measure of income inequality.

health_opportunity_indicator.long_description: A group of indicators that provide broad insight into the overall opportunity Virginians have to live long and healthy lives based on the Social Determinants of Health. It is a hierarchical index that allows users to examine social determinants of health at multiple levels of detail in Virginia. It is made up of over 30 variables, combined into 13 indicators, grouped into four profiles, which are aggregated into a single Health Opportunity Index. The HOI is reported at both the census tract and county/independent city level.
health_opportunity_indicator.short_description: A group of indicators that provide broad insight into the overall opportunity Virginians have to live long and healthy lives.
health_opportunity_indicator.statement: The health opportunity index in {features.name} is {value}.

hh_received_snap_cnt.long_description: The number of households in which at least one member of the household received benefits from the Food Stamp Program or the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) in the past 12 months.  This does not include households in which at least one member recieved benefits from WIC, the School Lunch Program, or assistance from food banks and not also from the Food Stamp Program or SNAP in the past 12 months.

hosp_3sfca.long_description: Hospital access score based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of facilities per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a facility is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for facilities (adult population).
hosp_3sfca.long_name: Hospital geographic availability (3-step floating catchment areas)
hosp_3sfca.short_description: Index of hospital availability based on supply and demand of facilities

sources.name: Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services

inadequate.long_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU) index, also known as the Kotelchuck index, with a rating of inadequate. Inadequate levels occurs when prenatal care begins in the 5th month or later or no prenatal care, regardless of the number of visits or, with less than 50% or more recommended visits received from 1st through 4th month.  The recommended number of prenatal care visits received from the time prenatal care began until the time of delivery is defined by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.
inadequate.long_name: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization: Inadequate
inadequate.short_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU): Inadequate

sources.name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

inadequate.statement: There are {value} cases rated as inadequate in {features.name}.

inadequate_pc.long_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU) index, also known as the Kotelchuck index, with a rating of inadequate. Proportion of pregnant mothers receiving inadequate prenatal care. Inadequate levels occurs when prenatal care begins in the 5th month or later or no prenatal care, regardless of the number of visits or, with less than 50% or more recommended visits received from 1st through 4th month.  The recommended number of prenatal care visits received from the time prenatal care began until the time of delivery is defined by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.
inadequate_pc.long_name: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization: Inadequate
inadequate_pc.short_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU): Inadequate

sources.name: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

inadequate_pc.statement: {value} of the cases in {features.name} rated as inadequate.

incarceration_rate_per_100000.long_description: The number of incarcerated people divided by the total population and then multiplied by 100,000. Allows ready comparison of the frequency of incarcerated between each census tract of different population sizes. Incarcerated people is number of people from each census tract in state prison or a local jail. Total population includes population of the census tract plus the imprisoned population.
incarceration_rate_per_100000.statement: The incarceration rate per 100,000 in {features.name} is {value}.

income_inequality_indicator.long_description: The Gini Index, a common measure of income inequality, measures whether the income earned within a community is distributed broadly or concentrated within the hands of small number of households.
income_inequality_indicator.short_description: The Gini Index, a common measure of income inequality.

intermediate.long_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU) index, also known as the Kotelchuck index, with a rating of intermediate. Intermediate prenatal care occurs when prenatal care begins from 1st through 4th month, and the proportion of the number of visits is between 50-79%.   The recommended number of prenatal care visits received from the time prenatal care began until the time of delivery is defined by the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists.

intermediate.short_description: Adequacy of Prenatal Care Utilization (APNCU): Intermediate

job_participation_indicator.long_description: The percentage of individuals 16-64 years of age active in the civilian labor force. It includes both those currently working and those seeking work.
job_participation_indicator.short_description: The percentage of individuals 16-64 years of age active in the civilian labor force.
job_participation_indicator.statement: The job participation indicator in {features.name} is {value}.

labor_participate_rate.long_description: The percentage of individuals aged 16 years and over in the labor force. In other words, the labor force participation rate is the number of people who are either working or actively looking for work. The labor force participation rate is often used by economists as an indicator of economic development and growth. /n Here the labor force includes all people classified in the civilian labor force and members of the members of the U.S. Armed Forces (people on active duty with the United States Army, Air Force, Navy, Marine Corps, or Coast Guard). The civilian labor force population consists of all people aged 16 and older who are classified as employed and unemployed. /n Based on American Community Survey Table 5-year estimates from 2015 to 2021. Labor force participation rate data is available at the tract, county and health district level for the state of Virginia.
labor_participate_rate.short_description: The percentage of individuals aged 16 years and over in the labor force.

sources.location: 5-Year estimates, table S2301_C02_001, via the API
sources.name: American Community Survey

labor_participate_rate.statement: {value} of the population in {region_name} is participating in the civilian job force.

_direct.long_description: and target regions, then the value of each block group is aggregated/disaggregated to any intersecting target region based on proportion of overlap.

_parcels.long_description: and parcels, then the value of each block group is divided across all living units within each intersecting parcel. mental_3sfca.long_description: Mental health services availability based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of facilities per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a facility is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for facilities (adult population).

number_food_insecure.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. This measure is an estimate of the number of people in food insecure households.  The brief providing the methodology of calculating these estimates is available at Feeding America's Map the Meal Gap website (linked below). Food insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
number_food_insecure.long_name: Estimated number of total people in food insecure households
number_food_insecure.short_description: Food insecure persons are people living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).

obgyn_2sfca.long_description: OBGYN care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of OBGYNs per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for OBGYNs (population served by OBGYNs). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online physician directory.
obgyn_2sfca.long_name: OBGYN care geographic availability (2-step enhanced floating catchment areas)
obgyn_2sfca.short_description: Index of OBGYN care availability based on supply and demand of providers

obgyn_3sfca.long_description: OBGYN care availability based on 3-step floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of OBGYNs per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for OBGYNs (population served by OBGYNs). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online physician directory.
obgyn_3sfca.long_name: OBGYN care geographic availability (3-step floating catchment areas)
obgyn_3sfca.short_description: Index of OBGYN care availability based on supply and demand of providers

obgyn_cnt.long_description: Count of OBGYN care providers based on provider locations. Address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
obgyn_cnt.short_description: Count of OBGYNs based on provider locations

obgyn_e2sfca.long_description: OBGYN care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of OBGYNs per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). othr_boys_pov_cnt.long_description: The count of individuals from other racial or ethnic groups (not white, African American, or Asian) who are boys and are living below the poverty line. This measure is based on 5-year ACS estimates and is calculated as the number of boys from other racial or ethnic groups below the poverty line within the specified geographic area.

othr_boys_pov_cnt.short_description: Count of boys from other racial or ethnic groups living below the poverty line based on 5-year ACS estimates.

othr_boys_pov_pct.long_description: The percentage of individuals from other racial or ethnic groups (not white, African American, or Asian) who are boys and are living below the poverty line. percent_food_insecure.long_description: Food insecurity refers to USDA's measure of lack of access, at times, to enough food for an active, healthy life for all household members and limited or uncertain availability of nutritionally adequate foods. This measure is an estimate of the percent of people in food insecure households.  The brief providing the methodology of calculating these estimates is available at Feeding America's Map the Meal Gap website (linked below). Food insecure households are not necessarily food insecure all the time. Food insecurity may reflect a household's need to make trade-offs between important basic needs, such as housing or medical bills, and purchasing nutritionally adequate foods.
percent_food_insecure.long_name: Estimated percentage of total people in food insecure households
percent_food_insecure.short_description: Food insecure persons are people living in households experiencing food insecurity (a lack of access to enough food for an active, healthy life).
percent_food_insecure.statement: {value} percent of the population in {features.name} are food insecure.

population_density_direct.long_description: Population density, or number of people per square mile, as calculated from census ACS population data and shapefile areas: \[\frac{population_{r}}{meters^{2}_{r}}1609.344^{2}\] Where r is each region (e.g., census tract or county). For non-census geographies, values are redistributed based on proportional overlap between census block groups and the local regions, using the redistribute R package.
population_density_direct.long_name: Population Density: People Per Square Mile (direct method)

population_density_parcels.long_description: Population density, or number of people per square mile, as calculated from census ACS population data and shapefile areas: \[\frac{population_{r}}{meters^{2}_{r}}1609.344^{2}\] Where r is each region (e.g., census tract or county). For non-census geographies, values are redistributed from census block groups to parcels, based on proportional geometric overlap and weighted by number of living units per parcel, then from parcels to the local regions based on proportional geometric overlap, using the redistribute R package.

primcare_2sfca.long_description: Primary care availability based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of physicians per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for physicians (population served by physicians). Provider address data were collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
primcare_2sfca.long_name: Primary care geographic availability (2-step enhanced floating catchment areas)
primcare_2sfca.short_description: Index of primary care physician availability based on supply and demand of providers
primcare_2sfca.statement: The primary care availability for {features.name} is {value}.

race_AAPI_count_direct.long_description: The Asian American/Pacific Islander population. 5-year ACS estimates in provided census geolevels. For non-census geolevels (such as zip codes), spatial overlaps are calculated between census block groups and target regions, then the value of each block group is aggregated/disaggregated to any intersecting target region based on proportion of overlap. Redistribution to non-census geolevels was performed using the redistribute R package.
race_AAPI_count_direct.short_name: The Asian American/Pacific Islander population direct

sources.location: 5-Year estimates, table B01001, via the API
sources.name: American Community Survey

sources.location: Health & Human Service > Human Services Regions
sources.name: Fairfax County Geospatial Data

race_AAPI_count_direct.statement: The Asian American/Pacific Islander population is {value} in {region_name}.

race_AAPI_count_parcels.long_description: The Asian American/Pacific Islander population. 5-year ACS estimates in provided census geolevels. For non-census geolevels (such as zip codes), spatial overlaps are calculated between census block groups and parcels, then the value of each block group is divided across all living units within each intersecting parcel. Once parcel-level values are assigned, spatial overlaps are calculated between parcels and target regions such that parcel values can be aggregated to each intersecting target region based on proportion of overlap. Redistribution to non-census geolevels was performed using the redistribute R package.
race_AAPI_count_parcels.short_name: The Asian American/Pacific Islander population parcels

sources.location: 5-Year estimates, table B01001, via the API
sources.name: American Community Survey

sources.name: Fairfax County Geospatial Data

race_AAPI_percent_parcels.long_description: The Asian American/Pacific Islander population percent. 5-year ACS estimates in provided census geolevels. For non-census geolevels (such as zip codes), spatial overlaps are calculated between census block groups and parcels, then the value of each block group is divided across all living units within each intersecting parcel. Once parcel-level values are assigned, spatial overlaps are calculated between parcels and target regions such that parcel values can be aggregated to each intersecting target region based on proportion of overlap. Redistribution to non-census geolevels was performed using the redistribute R package.

schoolFundAdequacy.long_description: The average gap in dollars between the actual and required spending per pupil among public school districts. Required spending is an estimate of dollars needed to achieve U.S. average test scores in each district.
schoolFundAdequacy.short_description: Average gap in dollars between actual and required spending per pupil in school districts.
schoolFundAdequacy.statement: The average gap between actual and required spending per pupil is {value} in {features.name}.

schools_2year_all.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) qualifying 2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
schools_2year_all.short_description: Number of 2-year schools per 100k people over 14, calculated within floating catchment areas.

sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics
sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics

schools_2year_all.statement: There are {value} 2-year schools per 100k people over 14 in {region_name}.

schools_2year_min_drivetime.long_description: Minimal drive time to a schools authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates from the Census block group centroid, as calculated by the Open Source Routing Machine. School locations are from the National Center for Education Statistics. All distances are calculated at the block group level, then averaged up to higher-level geographies.
schools_2year_min_drivetime.short_description: Drive time to the nearest 2-year schools.

sources.location: Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System, Institutional Characteristics
sources.name: National Center for Education Statistics

schools_2year_min_drivetime.statement: It takes {value} to drive to the nearest 2-year school from {region_name}'s block group centroids on average.

schools_2year_with_biomedical_program.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates with biomedical programs (any with Classification of Institutional Programs [CIP] codes starting with 26) per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) qualifying 2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.
schools_2year_with_biomedical_program.long_name: 2-year schools with biomedical programs per 100k people over 14
schools_2year_with_biomedical_program.short_description: Number of 2-year schools with biomedical programs per 100k people over 14, calculated within floating catchment areas.

schools_2year_with_computer_program.long_description: Number of schools authorized to award Associates degrees or 2-year or longer certificates with science programs (any with Classification of Institutional Programs [CIP] codes starting with 11) per 100k people over 14, based on 3-step floating catchment areas defined by distance. Catchment areas were calculated using (a) qualifying 2-year schools as listed by the National Center for Education Statistics, with supply values of 1, (b) Census block groups, with supply values as the population over the age of 14 as reported the American Community Survey 5-year summaries, and (c) distances between school locations and block group centroids, weighted by a Gaussian function with a scaling parameter set to 18, as calculated by the catchment R package.

segregation_indicator.long_description: A measure of whether and how much people of different racial and ethnic backgrounds live together in diverse communities. It includes measures of both community diversity and the distance between communities with different racial or ethnic profiles.

snap_shortfall_weighted_mean.long_description: The average SNAP shortfall is the estimated dollar amount that a household lacks to pay for their food costs. SNAP benefit is the dollar amount of dollars that a household may receive for supplemental food assistance after eligibility.  The SNAP shortfall is the ratio between the SNAP benefit divided by the food shortfall money.  The weighted average uses the number of households in different income categories, household combination and geography, and average is estimated for every census tract.
snap_shortfall_weighted_mean.short_description: The average SNAP shortfall is the estimated dollar amount that a household lacks to pay for their food costs

sources.name: U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development
Department   of Labor Women’s Bureau National
National   Bureau of Economic Research’s program TAXSIM Version 35

snap_shortfall_weighted_mean.statement: The average SNAP shortfall for households in {features.name} is {value}.

snap_weighted_mean.long_description: Weighted mean average of the dollar amount of Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) benefit. The financial benefit is estimated following the guidelines and procedures from the Virginia Department of Social Services. The weighting component corresponds to the number of households in different income categories, household combinations, and geographies. The weighted average is obtained for every census tract.
snap_weighted_mean.short_description: Weighted mean average dollar amount of SNAP benefits

veteran_count_direct.long_description: The Veteran population. 5-year ACS estimates in provided census geolevels. For non-census geolevels (such as zip codes), spatial overlaps are calculated between census block groups and target regions, then the value of each block group is aggregated/disaggregated to any intersecting target region based on proportion of overlap. Redistribution to non-census geolevels was performed using the redistribute R package.

sources.location: 5-Year estimates, table B21001, via the API
sources.name: American Community Survey

sources.location: Health & Human Service > Human Services Regions
sources.name: Fairfax County Geospatial Data

veteran_count_parcels.long_description: The Veteran population. 5-year ACS estimates in provided census geolevels. For non-census geolevels (such as zip codes), spatial overlaps are calculated between census block groups and parcels, then the value of each block group is divided across all living units within each intersecting parcel. Once parcel-level values are assigned, spatial overlaps are calculated between parcels and target regions such that parcel values can be aggregated to each intersecting target region based on proportion of overlap. Redistribution to non-census geolevels was performed using the redistribute R package.

sources.location: 5-Year estimates, table B21001, via the API
sources.name: American Community Survey

sources.location: Health & Human Service > Human Services Regions

walkability_index_raw.long_description: The Walkability Index is derived from the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) National Walkability Index. The National Walkability Index is a nationwide geographic data resource that ranks block groups according to their relative walkability. The National Walkability Index was developed using selected variables on density, diversity of land uses, and proximity to transit from the EPA Smart Location Database. The block group dataset is aggregated using population-weighted mean to Census tracts, counties, and Health Districts.
walkability_index_raw.short_description: A measure of how walkable a community is.

walkability_indicator.long_description: A measure of how walkable a community is based on residential and employment density, land use (destination) diversity, street connectivity and public transit accessibility.
walkability_indicator.short_description: A measure of how walkable a community is.

wellness_disparity_indicator.long_description: A measure of the disparate access to health services within a community. It includes the access to care indicator and the segregation indicator.
wellness_disparity_indicator.short_description: A measure of the disparate access to health services within a community.

_direct.long_description: and target regions, then the value of each block group is aggregated/disaggregated to any intersecting target region based on proportion of overlap.

_parcels.long_description: and parcels, then the value of each block group is divided across all living units within each intersecting parcel. Once parcel-level values are assigned, spatial overlaps are calculated between parcels and target regions such that parcel values can be aggregated to each intersecting target region based on proportion of overlap.

{variant.name}{category.name}.long_description: {variant} 5-year ACS estimates in provided census geolevels. For non-census geolevels (such as zip codes), spatial overlaps are calculated between census block groups {category} Redistribution to non-census geolevels was performed using the redistribute R package.
